pageContext.name: from-bs-as
pageContext.prefixed:
<tei-TEI data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" data-origname="TEI" data-origatts="xmlns:xi xmlns">
 <tei-teiHeader data-origname="teiHeader">
     <tei-fileDesc data-origname="fileDesc">
        <tei-titleStmt data-origname="titleStmt">
           <tei-title data-origname="title">A title</tei-title>
        </tei-titleStmt>
        <tei-publicationStmt data-origname="publicationStmt">
           <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
        </tei-publicationStmt>
        <tei-sourceDesc data-origname="sourceDesc">
           <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
        </tei-sourceDesc>
     </tei-fileDesc>
 </tei-teiHeader>
 <tei-text data-origname="text">
 <!--DANI-->
   <tei-body data-origname="body">
      <tei-div data-origname="div">
         <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Monſieur</tei-roleName> <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Acarete du Biscay's</tei-persName> Journey from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName> to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName"><tei-country data-origname="country">Peru</tei-country></tei-placeName>.</tei-head>
      </tei-div>
      <tei-div data-origname="div">
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>I Left <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>, and took the Road I 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Cordoua</tei-placeName>, leaving <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Santa Fe</tei-placeName> on my 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>right hand, of which place take this ac
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>count, 'tis a Spaniſh Settlement dependant 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>upon <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>, the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Commander</tei-roleName> is 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>no more than a <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Lieutenant</tei-roleName>, and does no
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>thing but by order from the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Governor</tei-roleName> 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>. 'Tis a little place con
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>taining <tei-measure data-origname="measure">25 Houſes</tei-measure>, without any Walls, 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Fortifications, or Garriſon, diſtant <tei-measure data-origname="measure">80 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Leagues</tei-measure> from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName> Northward, 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Situate upon the <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">River de la Plata</tei-geogName>, large 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Veſſels might come up to it, were it not 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>for a great bank that obstructs the pas
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>sage a little above <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>. Ne
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>vertheleſs 'tis a very advantageous Poſt, 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>because 'tis the only passage from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName"><tei-country data-origname="country">Peru</tei-country></tei-placeName>, 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/><tei-placeName data-origname="placeName"><tei-country data-origname="country">Chili</tei-country></tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Tucuman</tei-placeName> to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName"><tei-country data-origname="country">Paraguay</tei-country></tei-placeName>, and in a 
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>manner the Magazine of the Commodi
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ties
         </tei-p>
      </tei-div>
      <tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ties drawn from thence, particularly that 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Herb already ſpoken of, which they 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cannot be without in thoſe Provinces. 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>The Soil is as good and Fertile here as 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>; and the Town having 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>nothing remarkably different from what 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>has been observ'd of Buenos Ayres, I 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>leave it, and proceed upon my Jour
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ney. 'Tis counted 140 Leagues from 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Buenos Ayres to Cordoua, and becauſe 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ſome parts of the Road are uninhabited 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>for a long way together; I ſurnished 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>my ſelf at my departure with what I 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>was inform'd I ſhould ſtand in need 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of; ſo I ſet out having a Savage for my 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Guide, with Three Horſes and Three 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Mules, ſome to carry my Baggage, and 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>the reſt to change upon the way when 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>that I rid upon was tired. 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>From Buenos Ayres, to the River Lu
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>can, and even as far as the River Recife, 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>30 Leagues, I pass’d by several Habita
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>tions and Farms cultivated by the Spani
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ards, but beyond Recife to the River 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Salladillo, I ſaw none. Let it be obſer
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ved by the way, that theſe Rivers as well 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>as all the reſt in the Provinces of Buenos 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Ayres, Paraguay and Tucuman, that fall 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>into the River de la Plata are fordable 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>on Horſe-back; but when the Rains or 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>any</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div">
<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>any other accident ſwells them, a Tra<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>veller muſt either ſwim over, or elſe get <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>upon a bundle in the nature of a raft, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>which a Savage hawls over to the other <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ſide. I could not Swim, and ſo was <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>forc'd to make uſe of this expedient <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>twice or thrice when I could not find a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Ford. The way was this, my Indian <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>kill'd a Wild Bull, flead the Hide off, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ſtuffed it with ſtraw, and ty'd it up in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>a great bundle with thongs of the ſame <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Hide, upon which I plac'd my ſelf with <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>my Baggage ; he ſwam over hawling me <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>after him by a Cord ty'd to the bundle, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>and then he repaſs'd and ſwam my Horſes <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>and Mules over to me.
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>All the Country between the River <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Recife and Salladillo, tho' uninhabited, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>abounds in Cattle and all ſorts of Fruit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>trees, except Walnut and Chesnut-trees; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>there are whole Woods of Nectarine-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Trees, Three or Four Leagues in compaſs, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>that bear excellent Fruit, which they <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>not only eat raw, but bake them, or dry <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>them in the Sun, to keep, as we in France <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>do Prunes: They ſeldom uſe any other <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>than the Wood of this Tree for common <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>firing at Buenos Ayres, and thereabouts. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>The Savages that dwell in theſe Parts are <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>diſtinguiſh'd into two sorts, those that <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>volun-</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<!--GRACIELA-->
<tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>voluntarily ſubmit to the Spaniards are <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>call’d Panpiſtas, the reſt Serranos, both <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cloathed with Skins, but the laſt ſet up <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>on the Panpiſtas as their mortal Enemies <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>wherever they meet with them. All <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Fight on Horſe-back, either with Lances <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>pointed with Iron or Bones ſharpen'd, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>or else with Bows and Arrows, they <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>wear Bulls-hides faſhion'd like a Doublet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>without ſleeves, to defend their Bodies. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Their Chiefs that command over them <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>in War and Peace, are call’d Couracas. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>When they take any one of their Ene<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>mies, alive or dead, they meet all toge<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ther, and after they have reproach'd him, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>that either he or his Relations were the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>death of their Kindred or Friends, they <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cut and tear him into pieces, which they <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>roaſt a little and eat, making a drinking <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Bowl of his Scull. They feed moſtly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>upon flesh either raw or dreſs'd, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>particularly Colts fleſh, which they like! <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>better than Veal. They catch abundance <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of Fiſh likewiſe in their Rivers, They <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>have no ſettled places of aboad, but <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ramble up and down, ſeveral Families <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>together, and live in Tents. 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>I could not inform my ſelf exactly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>what Religion they were of, but I was <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>told that they look'd upon the Sun and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Moon</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p">Moon as Deities and as I travell'd along, I ſaw a Savage upon his knees with his Face to the Sun, who cry'd out and made ſtrange geſtures with his Hands and Arms. I learn'd from the Savage that accompany'd me, that he was one of thoſe they call'd Papas, who in the Morning kneel towards the Sun, and at Night towards the Moon, to ſupplicate those fancy'd Divinities to be propitious to them, to give them fair Weather, and Victory over their Foes. 
They make no great Ceremony in their Marriages ; but when a Relation dies, after they have rubb’d his body with a certain Earth that conſumes all but the Bones, they preserve them, and carry as many of them as they can conveniently about with them in a ſort of Cheſts, and this they do in token of their affection to their Kindred ; indeed they are not wanting in good Offices to them during their Lives, nor in their Sickneſs and Death. 
Along the River Salladillo, I took notice of a great many Parrats, or Papagays, as the Spaniards call them, and certain Birds, call’d Guacamayos, which are of divers Colours, and twice or thrice as big as a Parrat. The River it ſelf is full
</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<!--NICO-->

<tei-div data-origname="div">
   <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>full of the Fi<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>h, call'd Dorado, which is
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>very good to eat. There is al<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>o a Crea-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ture in it, whether 'tis Meat or Poy<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>on
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>no body knows, it has Four Feet and a long Tail like a Lizard.
   </tei-p>
   <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>From Salladillo quite to Cordoua, you
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>go along a very fine River, that abounds
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>with Fi<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>h, which is neither wide
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>nor deep, for it may be forded over. On
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>the Bank of it you meet with little Plan-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>tations every Three or Four Leagues ;
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>which are like Country Hou<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>es inhabi-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ted by Spaniards, Portuguese, and the Na-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>tives, who have all the nece<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg><tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ary acco-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>modation<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg> of Life they can wi<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>h, and
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>are very Civil and Charitable to Stran-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>gers; their principal Wealth is in Hor-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/><tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>es and Mules, in which they Trade with
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>the Inhabitants of Peru.
   </tei-p>
   <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Cordoua is a Town Situate in a plea<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ant
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>and fruitful Plain upon the <tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ide of a
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>River, bigger and broader than that I
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>have ju<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>t <tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>poken of : 'Tis compos’d of
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>about 400 Houses, Built like tho<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>e of
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Buenos Ayres. It has neither Ditches,
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>nor Walls, nor Fort for its defence; He
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>that Commands it is Governor of all the
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Provinces of Tucuman, and tho’ it be
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>the place of his ordinary Residence, yet
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>he is wont now and then, as he <tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ees oc-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ca<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ion,
   </tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div">
   <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ca<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ion, to go and pa<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>s <tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ome time at St.
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Jago de l’E<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>tro, at St. Miguel de Tucuman,
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>(which is the Capital City of the Province)
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>at Salta and at Xuxui. In each of the<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>e
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Villages there is a Lieutenant, who has
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>under him an Alcalde and <tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ome Officers
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>for the Admini<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>tration of Ju<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>tice. The
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Bi<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>hop of Tucuman likewi<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>e u<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ually re-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/><tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ides at Cordoua, where the Cathedral
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>is the only Pari<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>h Church of the whole
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Town, but there are divers Convents
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of Monks, namely of Dominicans, Recol-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>lects, and those of the Order de la Mer-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cy: and one of Nunns. The Jesuits
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>have a College there, and their Chappel
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>is the fine<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>t and riche<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>t of all.
   </tei-p>
   <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>The Inhabitants are Rich in Gold
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>and Silver, which they get by the Trade
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>they have for Mules, with which they
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>furni<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>h Peru and other Parts; which is
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/><tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>o con<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>iderable, that they <tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ell about 28
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>or 30000 of 'em every Year, which they
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>breed up in their Farms. They usually
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>keep 'em till they are about Two Years
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>old, then expose 'em to Sale, and have
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>about Six Patagons a piece for 'em. The
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Merchants that come to buy 'em, carry
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>'em to St. Jago, to Salta and Xuxui ,
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>where they leave 'em for Three Years,
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>till they are well grown and become
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/><tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>trong,
   </tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div">
   <tei-p data-origname="p">
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/><tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>trong, and afterwards bring 'em to Pe-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ru, where they pre<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ently have Vent for
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>'em, becau<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>e there as well as in the re<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>t 
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of the Western part of America, the
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>greate<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>t part of their Carriage is upon
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Mules. The People of Cordoua al<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>o
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>drive a Trade in Cow<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>, which they have
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>from the Countrey of Buenos Ayres, and
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>carry to Peru, where without this way
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of Sub<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>i<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>tance 'tis certain they would
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>have much ado to live. This kind of
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Traffick makes this Town the mo<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>t con-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/><tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>iderable in the Province of Tucuman,
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>as well for its Riches and Commodities,
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>as for the Number of its Inhabitants,
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>which are counted to be at lea<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>t 5 or
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>600 Families, be<tei-reg data-origname="reg">s</tei-reg>ides Slaves who are
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>three times the number. But the gene
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>-rality of 'em of all degrees have no other
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Arms but a Sword and Poignard, and
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>are very indifferent Souldiers, the Air
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of the Country, and the Plenty they
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>enjoy, rendring them Lazy and Cow-
      <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ardly.
   </tei-p>
</tei-div>

</tei-body>
</tei-text>
</tei-TEI>
